reviewText: In 1988, Krzysztof Kieslowski gave us two `short films' about opposite yet connected subjects, love and violence.  For me, the more effective of the two is clearly his film about love.  That isn't to say that his look at killing is not effective or stale, but it doesn't quite reach the levels of depth that he brings to his dissection of love and all things associated.Here, Kieslowski develops a film that calls to mind the films of Michael Haneke, a man who has built his career on exploiting violence and discovering its origins.  Where `A Short Film About Killing' falls short though is in the climax.  Haneke builds films around this subject with a keen eye for the details and delivers seemingly anti-climactic conclusions that speak volumes for the familiarity of violence.  `A Short Film About Killing' attempts to color in this depiction and in the end fails to give us an answer.  It merely suggests a possibility, but even at that it doesn't quite connect the way that it could have.The lives of a taxi driver, a hoodlum and a lawyer are all thrust into one another when a bizarre act of violence ties them together, and this premise is ripe for intelligent desertion.  Sadly, when the film draws to its climax it brings with it a open-end, which doesn't suit the film's buildup.Still, Kieslowski holds our attention with riveting camerawork, sensational cinematography and edits that keep us glued.  The score, the performances and the manipulated atmosphere are not to be taken lightly.  From a purely technical standpoint, this film soars.  I just wish that the same amount of embellishment was given to the script.
summary: A technical marvel that falls short at the climax...

reviewText: Despite its title, this a a full length movie shown with subtitles from the original Polish.  It is a creepy film noire with rarely shown portrayals of day-to-day life in cold war era Warsaw.  Lots of suspense and fascinating characters make for an unusal and intense visual experience.

reviewText: As powerful and harrowing a film as you are likely to see. This film expands an episode ("Thou Shalt Not Kill") from Kieslowski's Decalogue. SPOILER ALERT: It is virtually impossible to discuss the film without talking about the plot; those who want to see the film without any prior knowledge of the film should stop here. The film is divided into three parts. In the first part we jump back and forth among three characters - a young man wandering about the streets of Warsaw, committing random nasty acts; a cab driver; and a law student who has just passed the Polish equivalent of the bar exam. The three lives intersect through a series of random events. The second part is the preparation for and the brutal murder of the cabbie by the young man. The third part is the preparation for and the execution of the young man, whom the young lawyer has unsuccessfully defended. Interestingly, we do not see how the young man was caught; we see none of the trial - we don't know what the explanation for the murder was or what defense was used. We simply briefly see the end of the judicial session and the young man's simple question: ("Is this the end?"). Kieslowski obviously chose the title of his film carefully: it is indeed a short film (about 80 minutes, but expanded from the shorter 55-minute version in the Decalogue), and it is solely about killing: the senseless killing of the cabbie by the young man (lasting a seemingly endless 15 minutes), and the "legal killing" of the young man by the State via the death penalty. Kieslowski is not interested in the background of the characters (though at the end we do learn a little about the condemned man), but rather only the act of killing, whether by the individual or by society. The film is not overtly anti-capital punishment: Kieslowski "objectively" presents a cold-blooded murder (much like in Dead Man Walking, there is no doubt about the accused's guilt) and leaves it to the viewer to make his/her own moral judgment regarding the death penalty. This one will stay with you long after the final credits roll off.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A truly amazing film - I cannot promise that you will enjoy it, in fact I can almost guarantee that you will find it disturbing and difficult to watch. This is not because of the quality of the film, which is outstanding, but because of the subject matter and the directness with which it is tackled.It is a film about two killings - the murder to a taxi driver by a young man and the trial and execution of the same young man by the state. There is little editorial, the films simply presents both killings in their full horrific detail. The murder of the taxi driver feels interminable as with no warning or explanation he is strangled and then battered to death with a slab. He execution of the young man is, if anything even more harrowing, as he is dragged kicking, screaming and crying to the noose. As is often the case it is the little things that are the most chilling and leave the longest lasting impact: the tears of the condemned boy, the pan to collect the human waste.In my opinion Kieslowski was the greatest European filmmaker of the twentieth century and this film is one of his best.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Part of the famed "Decalogue" series Polish director Kieslowski created for television, "Killing" is a moody, thought-provoking meditation on the Fifth Commandment. Is Jacek's atrocity crueler than state-sanctioned murder? Is capital punishment morally defensible? As his troubled characters wander benighted cityscapes in a world heavy with ominous portents--including the bleak opening shot of a dead rat and hanged cat--Kieslowski masterfully weighs the balance.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Bottom Line:A perfect example of why some things do not need to be expanded, this adaptation of a 55-minute TV show episode into a 85 minute film begins with one of the most boring sequences I've ever witnessed in a film (the director films through a yellow lens, for some reason, the main character walking around Poland for literally 20 minutes without saying more than 20 words) before Kieslowski moves on to a brutal murder and an exploration of the death penalty; at 55 minutes this would be compelling, but with the extra half hour I cannot recommend this leadenly paced film despite its interesting material in the latter half.2.5/4
Title: N/A

reviewText: Krzysztof Kieslowski's "A Short Film About Killing" is an extended version of his episode V of "The Decalogue."  It is about 24 minutes longer in length than its television series counterpart, but is basically the same film just fleshed out a bit.  As the title suggests, this film is about killing and revolves around the lives of three people: a mean spirited cab driver who is the victim, the reckless young man who is the killer, and an ambitious young lawyer who defends him.It portrays events where a life is taken by a killer and then the state uses the same method to punish the killer.  In a sense, the film is about the death penalty, but does not make any obvious conclusions on the ethical use of this punishment.  It merely shows the events that lead up to the murder, the murder itself, and the state handing out the punishment.  The killer and victim both got on my nerves in the events leading up to the murder, as both of them were annoying people often reckless and inconsiderate of others.  Interestingly enough, the victim and killer shared more in common than this, as the victim was choked with a rope, and the killer was hung with a rope.  We truly have an "eye for an eye" punishment, adding some symbolism to the film.The move was very emotional and thoroughly depressing as it depicts the insanity of one who takes the life of another and reminds us that this really is the crazy world in which we live in.  Although this is not one of my favorite films by Kieslowski, it really is a work of art and seems to be more appreciated by those outside Poland than by the people in it.
summary: An extended version of episode V of "The Decalogue"
Title: N/A
